This is NPR News.
Is Pakistan fighting hard enough against al-Qaida and the Taliban?
That's a growing concern for the Bush administration; a question when Pakistan's new prime minister, Yousuf Raza Gillani, visited the White House yesterday.
Gillani's Washington trip coincided with a U.S.
missile strike along the Pakistan border that may have killed a top al-Qaida bomb-making specialist.
Pakistan's government has repeatedly complained about unilateral American strikes against militants.
This time the prime minister was in Washington to deliver that complaint publicly on CNN.
There should be more cooperation on their intelligence side so that when there is a credible and actionable information given to us, we will hit ourselves.
We turn now to Rashid Rahman(ph).
He's editor of the Post newspaper in Lahore, Pakistan.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Are there any more details about that strike?
Reports here say that a top bomb maker was killed along with six others.
Yes.
Our media has carried that report, but the military authorities, their information wing has said that they are still gathering information; they don't have any confirmed reports on that.
However, all the international media sources, wire agencies, are confirming that this gentleman was taken out.
And this was a top al-Qaida official.
Apparently he was a weapons expert, a bomb-making expert, and some reports claim a poisons expert.
Let's turn back to the Pakistani prime minister.
He has been in office since February.
He leads a government that's widely considered weak.
So how much power does he actually have, and does a strike like this hurt him?

Well, I think not withstanding all the assurances that are being touted in Washington about pursuing the war on terror, this weak government - as you quite rightly describe it - has come out with a policy which wants to have a judicious mix of negotiations with militants.
It wants to bring development to the tribal areas, to wean people away from militancy, and it wants to use force only as a last resort if all else fails.
However, there are enormous problems.
I think the most important problem is that the military and its intelligence arm - the famous, or should I say notorious, ISI...
That's the intelligence agency.
...are not necessarily obeying the civilian government's orders.

In fact, just before he left for Washington, the government issued a notification to the effect that the ISI would be transferred from answering to the prime minister to being answerable to the Interior Ministry.
However, there was an immediate reaction and the notification was subsequently withdrawn.
That fiasco highlights the problem that the civilian government faces of control over the military and its intelligence arms.

The strike that has taken place also highlights the impatience that is growing in Washington with the possibility that there are elements within the intelligence agencies which are still wedded to a Taliban victory in Afghanistan and perhaps even leaking information if intelligence is shared before the strikes.
Now, one of the things that Gillani came to talk about was U.S.
military aid for Pakistan military, in particular an upgrade of the F-16 fighter jet, so he can take Pakistani money and use it to boost the economy.
Is that another problem for him?
Well, the economy is in dire straits.

Though I can only say that although there were high hopes that on the war on terror assurances by the prime minister would help to allay whatever concerns there are in Washington about safe havens in the tribal areas and the ability of the militants to conduct cross-border attacks into Afghanistan and aid for the Pakistani economy, perhaps less is available than was hoped for.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
Rashid Rahman is editor of the Post newspaper in Lahore, Pakistan.

Well, what's remarkable about the documents is what's not in there, and what's not in there is any substantiated evidence of voter misconduct at any scale.
In fact, one of the troubling things about the documents that we saw was that before we were even really meeting, commission staff were working on a framework of a report.
And several sections of report talk about voter fraud, and those sections are completely blank.
They didn't insert any information whatsoever.

So that's why we've been saying that, even though the idea was to investigate voter fraud, it is pretty clear that the purpose of the commission was to actually affirm and validate the president's claims whether or not we had any evidence of any such voter misconduct.
And, again, you were on the panel, but you couldn't get access to the work it was doing or any evidence that it was supposedly gathering.
I couldn't even get a schedule.

This was the frustration that I felt when Minnesota Secretary of State Steve Simon forwarded me an email from the Minnesota Voters Alliance touting the fact that they've been invited to the December meeting of the commission, and that was the first word I'd had in October that they were even talking about a December meeting.
So that's when I sent the formal letter which really led ultimately to the lawsuit you're talking about.
And, along the way, you shared your concerns with other members of the group?
I did.

And one of the things that came out in these documents was a probate judge from Alabama, Alan King, who was one of the other Democrats on the commission, unbeknownst to me, had also sent a similar piece of correspondence to mine asking for what we were doing, what was going on.
And he didn't get an answer, either.
Kris Kobach is, of course, the secretary of state of Kansas.
He was the vice chair of this commission appointed by President Trump.
When the commission was disbanded, neither Kobach nor the president said, we're disbanding it because it didn't find anything.
They said there were legal issues.
They had other reasons.
What were you told at the time regarding why the commission was being folded?

The only thing that we were told at the time - and it came very suddenly - was that, because of all the lawsuits, it was impossible for the commission to do its work, which I find absolutely laughable.
As the chief elections officer, chief motor vehicle officer, chief notary officer, etc., for the state of Maine, I get sued about five times a week.
If I stopped doing my work because of pending litigation, we'd come grinding to a halt.
It just simply does not follow that the White House cannot have a commission do its work because there's litigation.
That's what the Department of Justice is for.
You let them handle the litigation, and you keep doing your work.

I think the reason why they disbanded it was because they really didn't want anybody to know what they were talking about and working on behind the scenes, which was this report that was being framed up without any of our knowledge.
We hadn't even done any substantive discussion about what a report would look like, and they were writing it.

So I think that speaks to what the goal was, which was to validate the president's claims - not to do any type of investigation or explication of what those claims would actually look like or produce.
You were happy to be on this commission.
It's just the way this commission went about its business.
Yeah.
I mean, I was - I came into it with the idea that we could tell our story.
We do a great job in our elections here in Maine, and people trust what we do.
And I thought, that's a great story to tell.
But we never really got a chance to tell it because the focus of the work of the commission seemed to be on, you know, this phantom menace of voter fraud that you can't quantify it.
Nobody ever shows me indictments.
They never show me prosecutions during the time of the commission.
People would send me Facebook memes about (laughter) you know, the number of illegal immigrants voting.
It's like, OK, that's a great fairy tale, but show me the actual concrete evidence.
And no one seems to be able to come up with that, either now or during the time of the commission.
Matthew Dunlap is the secretary of state of the state of Maine.
Thanks for being with us today.
Thanks for having me.
And we should say we have reached out to Secretary Kris Kobach, the former vice chair of the commission, and are awaiting his response.
News now on the earthquake that caused a tsunami to hit the Solomon Islands -that's about a thousand miles northeast of Australia - that occurred overnight.
Reports say at least 13 people have died, but they're still counting everything that's happened there.
Robert Iroga is editor of The Solomon Star newspaper.
Mr. Iroga, welcome to DAY TO DAY.
Tell us, what is the latest there?
Well, the latest, as far as we know, is a lot of boats have gone down tonight, down to the provinces that were hit by the earthquake and obviously the tsunami for relief supplies.
They are trying to get food to the people who are affected by the tsunami.
You have managed to speak to people in the region that was really hit hardest by the tsunami by telephone, and what have they been telling you?
Well, they've been telling us that they saw huge waves hitting - I mean, coming straight at them and then started to throw buildings on the sea and some on the floor of the ground.
And people were rushing for safety in the higher, higher grounds, or higher land, and those were the people who survived.
And when the waves went by, a lot of things were carried back into the sea, including human beings as well.
So the story wasn't really good, and a lot of the environment was also damaged.
What time of day was it when the tsunami struck?
Well, it struck at 7:40 a.m. in the morning Solomon Islands time on a Monday, the 2nd of April, 2007.
